titleStmt.title: Little robin red breast; a collection of pretty songs, for the instruction and amusement of children: : entirely new.

availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: Little robin red breast; a collection of pretty songs, for the instruction and amusement of children: : entirely new.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed by Isaiah Thomas, and sold at his bookstore.,

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: LITTLE ROBIN RED BREAST; A COLLECTION OF PRETTY SONGS, For the INSTRUCTION and AMUSEMENT of CHILDREN: ENTIRELY NEW.
WORCESTER, (MASSACHUSETTS) PRINTED BY ISAIAH THOMAS, AND SOLD AT HIS BOOK-STORE. MDCCLXXXVI.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: LITTLE darling, quickly riſe,
Morning bluſhes in the ſkies;
Now the proſpect all is gay,
Riſe to work, to 〈◊〉 , or play.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Do not uſe "the Sluggard's guiſe,
"Loth to go to bed or riſe:"
Think how ſweet is early day,
Riſe, my darling! come away.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Molly will the fire prepare;
Cakes and tea ſhall be your fare;
Breakfaſt waits. Make haſte, I pray,
Take it, love;—then come away.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Look! the kitten on the hearth,
With the morning, wakes to mirth:
Pretty little Puſs will play,
When ſhe ſees the morning gay.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: Don't you hear the gentle dove
Cooing in the neighb'ring grove?
While the tender lambkins play,
All to hail the riſing day.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: And the bee in roſy bow'rs,
Sipping honey from the flow'rs;
Little creature, ſeems to pay
Tribute to the early day.

lg.head: VII.
lg.l: Sleep, you know, was made for night,
Not to waſte the golden light;
Thoſe that ſleep their time away,
Don't deſerve the ſight of day.

lg.head: VIII.
lg.l: Let the naughty children lie,
You are no ſuch LULLABY;
Minding what your parents ſay,
You will riſe to read or play.

lg.head: IX.
lg.l: Early hours are good for health;
Early riſing leads to wealth;
Whether 'tis for work or play,
Learn to riſe with riſing day!

lg.head: I.
lg.l: COME Harry and Polly, and
Billy anti Dolly,
My play-fellows all, hither come;
With manners ſo pretty, a while
leave the city,
And ramble a little from home.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: We ſhall all be delighted, and none will be ſlighted,
Our nurſes too with us ſhall come;
And we'll all be playing, the time ſweet delaying,
'Till ev'ning ſhall warn us—go home.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: While we are well treated, our pleaſure completed,
Sure all the good children will come;
As in innocent ſporting new pleaſures we're courting,
We ſhall dream of them when we go home.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Our joys thus o'erflowing, no cares nor ills knowing,
As none that are naughty muſt come;
By all thus regarded, and prais'd and rewarded,
How merrily we ſhall go home!

lg.head: I.
lg.l: TELL me not of ſilly fears,
Such as fooliſh children do!
Sudden ſtarts and cauſeleſs tears,
Deareſt! were not made for you.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: No!for you our darling are,
By your mother fondly preſt;
You are all your nurſe's care,
And by every friend careſs'd.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Don't you fear the bugbear crew,
Naughty boys that come to fright;
Don't you think they'll come to you,
If you ſleep without a light.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Light and darkneſs all the ſame,
With good boys and girls ſhould be;
Theſe indeed are but a name,
He that's good, from fear is free.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: Then, my child, in quiet reſt,
For, believe me, 'tis moſt true;
While with innocence you're bleſt,
Bugbears are not made for you.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: 'TIS a pretty bird, my deary,
See his wings are tipt with gold;
What a pity he ſhould fear ye,
But he ſhould not be too bold.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: In the woods had you firſt found him,
When he warbled from the ſpray;
When the joys of freedom crown'd him,
O! how ſweet, tho' wild his lay.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: But in bondage thus reſtraining,
Tho' he tunes his little voice,
Still his ſong is but complaining;
Can the captive e'er rejoice?

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Arts in time may tame and pleaſe him,
(Arts he never knew when free)
But in vain you ſtrive to pleaſe him,
While he pants for liberty.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: THE fiſh that wild ſports thro' the book,
Thinks the pleaſures of life are his own;
But when he's once caught on the hook,
Alas! all thoſe pleaſures are gone.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: The angler too ſure plies the bait,
Contriv'd to deprive him of breath;
In ſport ſee he ſwallows his fate,
And his pleaſures are ended in death.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: And ſuch is the fate of the child,
From his parents who wildly will run;
Altho' by falſe pleaſure beguil'd,
At laſt he is loſt and undone.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: WHEN SALLY was little, ſhe liv'd in a cot,
With her father, and mother, and aunt;
And tho', as it ſeems, they no riches had got,
Yet their darling did never know want.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: When SALLY grew bigger ſhe went to a ſchool,
And there, as her play-fellows tell,
She minded her learning, obſerv'd ev'ry rule,
For a while not a girl did ſo well.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: She was notic'd by many.—A gay lady fair,
Once took her with kindeſt intent;
She made the young SALLY her principal care,
And took her wherever ſhe went.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Now while SALLY was good ſhe liv'd like a queen;
What a pity ſhe does not ſo ſtill!
But with ſad wicked children at laſt ſhe was ſeen,
And ſhe'll go with them, ſay what you will.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: 'T was this made the lady young SALLY forſake,
No more would ſhe act a friend's part,
But the girl ſhe oblig'd to her own ways to take,
And her mother has broken her heart.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: Thus, now SALLY is naughty, ſhe's hated by all,
And, if ſhe don't mend in her ways,
By her obſtinate folly to ruin ſhe'll fall,
Tho' once ſhe had ev'ry one's praiſe.

lg.head: VII.
lg.l: Then think of young SALLY; take warning betimes,
Of bad company early beware;
if you join naughty children, you'll ſhare in their crimes,
And certainly fall in a ſnare.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: WHILE you ſmell at that roſe-bud, my love,
whilen its beautiful hue each admires,
Your mind you may aptly improve,
by leſſens which prudence inſpires.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: The flow'r is all gay to the ſight,
Its bluſh is like that of the morn;
But yet with its colours ſo bright,
Don't you ſee it is arm'd with a thorn.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: When you preſs it, be careful of harm,
Leſt your fingers unwary you wound;
If you ſhould, it no longer would charm,
Tho' with ſummer's choice beauties 'tis crown'd.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: No flow'r that adorns the gay green,
Indeed with the roſe can compare;
It is bright in ſimplicity ſeen,
The roſe is both uſeful and fair.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: But yet ev'ry ſweet has its ſour.
And all things on earth ſtill muſt cloy;
And godneſs alone has the pow'r,
To give us true comfort and joy.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: Then in ſearch of ſoft pleaſures, my dear,
As along life's gay ſtream you are borne,
All bright while the proſpects appear,
Pluck the roſe, but beware of the thorn.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: O'ER the fields, through the gardens we rove at our will,
For leave is now giv'n us to play;
So we'll take thus of innocent paſtime our fill,
And make holiday while we may.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: 'TIs becauſe we've been good that ſuch pleaſures we taſte,
Our'eſſons ſo ſoon we have learn'd;
That now we have leiſure which pays for our haſte,
No joys are like thoſe which are earn'n.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Then to Charley, to Jemmy, to Betſey we'll go,
But Peter the naughty we'll ſhun;
For we cannot true pleaſure in company know,
Of boys that from learning will run.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Little Charley and Jemmy their parents obey,
And Betſey's ſo good, that I find.
Her aunt has juſt given her a frock fine and gay,
And her friends are all loving and kind.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: When we leave off our ſporting, and home I return,
I know what Mamma will give me,
And my brother and ſiſter, for all in our turn
Will be happy and all will agree.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: And now to the pye-houſe you'll all take a race;
But ſtop a while 'till you ſtart fair;
Oh I ſee that young Tommy breaks firſt from his place,
Yet I'll catch him before he gets there.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: DID you ſee young pouting WATTY?
Did you ſee him late I pray?
He has been ſo very naughty,
That he can't go out to-day.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: See, now, at the door I ſpy him,
He for very ſpite and ſhame,
Bites his lip, don't let's go nigh him,
'Till he owns he is to blame.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: He's a ſtubborn boy, my Nancy,
Stubborn folks ne'er want for woe;
But correction will, I fancy,
Make him yet his errours know.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: If it does not, ſtill offending
All who wiſh him well to do;
Without any hope of mending,
Ruin muſt his ſteps purſue.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: Then let you and I take warning,
Early thus from others harm;
WATTY's faults in time diſcerning,
And by goodneſs learn to charm.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: SINGING, dancing, anticks, tumbling,
Trick on trick ſtill merry jumbling;
Full of laughing, joking, ſporting,
To the booths the crowd reſorting.
ſuch is a country fair, boys.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: People ſtill on people preſſing,
Players and their puppets dreſſing;
Some the pence together ſcraping,
Others quite employ'd in gaping.
Such is a country fair, boys.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: While the crowds thus oddly mixing,
Merry Andrew throws his tricks in;
Merry Andrew ſtill diverting,
For his tricks there is no hurt in.
Such is a country fair, boys.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Here are ribbands, caps, and laces,
Cakes and toys in other places;
All alike for ſhew diſplaying,
Chuſe at will, it is but paying.
Such is a country fair, boys.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: Nanny, Billy, Patty, Molly,
Little Ned and ſiſter Dolly;
All will go to ſpend their treaſure,
For the ſcene is full of pleaſure.
Such is a country fair, boys.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: IF you're given to boaſting, you'll never do well:
Be ſilent, but evermore ſtrive to excel;
And if you'll attend now a ſtory I'll tell.

l.hi: For ſweet modeſty's charms you may learn here;
The beauties of ſweet modeſty.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: There once was a BUTTERFLY gaudy and vain.
Who ſpy'd a poor mole creeping over the plain,
And ſhe view'd him indeed with an eye of diſdain.

l.hi: Sweet modeſty's charms you may learn here;
The beauties of ſweet modeſty.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: She quickly began his rough from to deſpiſe,
His creeping on earth and his want of bright eyes;
But the mole quite contented ſtill nothing replies.

l.hi: Sweét modeſty's charms you may learn here;
The beauties of ſweet modeſty.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: But a bird in his ſwiftneſs now ruſh'd thro' the air,
And ſoon made a prey of the inſect ſo fair;
While the mole ſtill jogg'd onward devoid of all care.

l.hi: Sweet modeſty's charms you may learn here;
The beauties of ſweet modeſty.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: Tho' the mole could not ſee yet he heard of her fate,
Quite happy, he neither was vain nor was great;
He was wiſe and content, nor repented too late.

l.hi: Sweet modeſty's charms you may learn here;
The beauties of ſweet modeſty.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: WHAT a ſweet and pretty creature
We have bury'd, Charles, to-day;
Oh! it ſung the ſongs of nature,
And has often made us gay.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: But 'twas wild and would be ſtraying,
Never could endure its cage;
And as thus all giddy ſtraying,
Chanc'd with PUSSY to engage.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Cruel PUSSY little caring
For his form or ſong ſo ſweet;
Ever watching and enſnaring,
Caus'd him ſoon his fate to meet.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Tho' we pity'd him when dying,
And his ſhroud and coffin made;
Yet indeed there's no denying,
He was by himſelf betray'd.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: Had he ſtay'd as friends would have him
In his cage or miſtreſs' room,
Puſs could not of life bereav'd him,
He had never met his doom.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: Wanton children, hence take warning,
Safeſt in your parents care;
When their gentle precepts ſcorning,
Ever ſure to meet a ſnare.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: HOW ſweet are the ſports of our youth,
What pleaſures with our's can [compare?
'Tis innocence pleaſes, and truth,
To an infant's what joys can compare?

lg.head: II.
lg.l: So eaſy the bliſe that we find,
While none are our care or our woe;
Our parents may feel in their mind,
But no troubles their little ones know.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: With peace and contentment we riſe,
If it be to our learning or play;
Let none our ſeet paſtimes deſpite,
Since lif's but the ſport of a day.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: The grave ones may think as they will,
But can gravity give them the [pow'r,
Like us to live merrily ſtill,
And happily ſpend the fleet hour.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: At marbles, at hoop, or at ball,
Or whatever the ſports that delight;
In the day it is exerciſe all,
And ſweetly we ſleep in the night.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: Tho' trifles we look for like theſe,
Do not men too their trifles purſue?
And gewgaws their fancies can pleaſe,
'T were well if as innocent too.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: WHILE the moon ſo ſweetly ſhining,
Makes the ſcene as bright as day;
Quite your whimp'ring, and your whining,
Aſk for leave, and come to play.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Sun-ſhine, to be ſure, is glaring,
By the day we work and read;
Yet with ſofter beauties cheering,
Ev'ning may its beauties plead.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Ev'nings like to theſe are pretty,
All is quiet and ſerene;
Patty for them quits the city,
Patty, mamma's little queen.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Look the ſtreams all ſilver running,
Hills all yellow'd o'er appear;
Woods the blaze of day-light ſhun-ning,
Yet are ſweetly brighten'd here.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: As each little paſtime varies,
By the pale, uncertain light;
Don't you look like little fairies,
Dancing in a ring by night?

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: But, tho' now the ſports may keep ye,
Early hours require your reſt;
Whether lively you or ſleepy,
Early hours are always beſt.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: WHAT do you ſee there my deary,
Which ſo much attracts your eyes,
That you draw the glaſs ſo near ye,
What freſh beauties there can riſe?

lg.head: II.
lg.l: 'Tis your face that you are viewing
Pretty infant, full of play;
But the years, their courſe purſuing,
Take at laſt all charms away.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: All but thoſe which Heav'n beſtowing,
On the mind which firm and ſure;
Thro' old age and ſickneſs glowing,
Still unfading ſhall endure.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Beauty is a ſhort-liv'd bleſſing,
As a gaudy ſhow admir'd;
Goodneſs merits our careſſing,
Moſt by all to be deſir'd.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: If the glaſs, is thus delighting,
Where a pretty face is ſeen;
Outward beauty ſo inviting,
Should remind of that within.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: Then, my darling, while intent you
View ſo cloſe a pretty face;
Think for what your Maker meant you,
Nor a lovely form diſgrace.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: DEAREST Betſey ſay,
When I was away,
Was your ſport and play,
Innocent and pretty.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Without diſguiſe,
Art or lies,
Truth I prize,
Aſk my ſiſter Kitty.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: She can tell,
Priſe knows well,
So does Bell,
All was good and pretty.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: We did read,
Sing indeed,
Ali agreed,
Charley ran with Kitty.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: In the ſhade,
Rings we made,
Laughing Play'd,
Was it not all pretty.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: Take a kiſs,
And for this,
Bell and Priſs
Shall ſup on tarts with Betty.
You are my darling yet,
O pretty, pretty BETT!

lg.head: I.
lg.l: MORNING now is paſt away,
On the fields the ſun-beams play;
From the ſchool returning ſoon,
See good boys go home at Noon.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Naughty children ſometimes ſtay,
Kept from dinner and from play;
You, my dear, and Kitty too,
Come the pleaſing ſcene to view.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Now before the dinner's got,
Let us walk to that green plot;
If the ſun too ſultry prove,
We may ſeek the ſhady grove.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: There your play-fellows you'll find,
They have left us far behind:
In the ſhed in yonder dale!
Dolly tends her cleanly pail!

lg.head: V.
lg.l: Don't you ſee the uſeful cow?
Don't you hear the creature low?
Thus ſhe gives her ſtore when due,
For ſyllabubs and puddings too.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: Still her milk for you ſhall flow,
Thither deareſt let us go;
There while we ſhall ſport and play,
Noon-tide hour will paſſ away.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: COME, come away,
For we muſt be gay,
Without any loſs,
Any hind'rance or croſs,
We ſha1l find,
What is moſt to our mind,
A boy that's ſo good, he can never have foes,
But pleaſure he meets with whereever he goes.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: And Sukey we find,
Good-natur'd and kind,
For her play-mates ſhe ſtill
Has good-nature at will,
To her miſtreſs or nurſe.
She never is worſe;
She never needs anger, nor frowning, nor blows,
But ſmiles muſt attend her wherever ſhe goes.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: So come all away,
To our meeting ſo gay,
Round the may-pole we'll dance
And in pleaſure advance,
Charles and Sukey ſhall be
Crown'd with garlands, you'll ſee.
Boys and girls, when ſo good, all diſtinction ſhall know,
And they ſhall have praiſes wherever they go.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: WHEN you live with your parents at home,
My infant how happy are you;
But When you are ſeeking to roam,
What evils alas! you purſue.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: If abroad you too careleſsly play,
What troubles you oftentimes meet!
Being loſt while you careleſsly ſtray,
Or run down by the folks in the ſtreet!

lg.head: III.
lg.l: 'Tis then that you wiſh to comeback,
To your parents and nurſes ſo kind;
Should you leave them at once, then [alack!
How many more troubles you'd find.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: The pets and the airs which you ſhow,
Tho' ſometimes corrected 'tis true;
That correction its good can beſtow,
My dear, 'tiS the better for you.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: 'T will be time enough many a long year,
For you through the wide world to roam;
And then you'll ſoon wiſh too, my dear,
That you'd ſtill been contented at home.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: Whate'er are the ſcenes you behold,
And various, indeed, they muſt be;
As oft' by your nurſe you've been told,
"Home is home, though 'tis homely," You'll ſee.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: CHILDREN, while you ſeek for pleaſure,
Don't you ſee the moments fly;
Mirth is your's, but keep in meaſure,
Though you laugh you ſoon may cry.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: But a Lott'ry, boys, this life is,
Moſt will loſe, though all muſt play;
All our time but full of ſtrife is,
You are happy in to-day.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Do not aſk about to-morrow,
Little wantons revel ſtill;
Future times bring care and ſorrow,
Soon, too ſoon, you'll have your fill.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Yet, content with play and ſports, you
Now may paſs the time away;
Fleeting movements, as they court you,
But invite to ſports and play.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: Like the beauties that ſurround you,
(Nature's beauties) which ne'er cloy;
While with innocence thus crown'd you
Ev'ry bleſſing ſhall enjoy.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: COME, leave off your ſchooling, to ſport and to play,
For we muſt be all gay and merry to-day;
It is young CHARLEY's birth-day.
We all muſt agree,
To viſit our play-mate good humour'd and free.
While he invites,
And pleaſure delights,
Who'll be ſo happy, ſo happy as we?

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Young CHARLEY is lov'd by the beſt in the town,
Good nature does ſtill all his qualities crown;
He is free and good humour'd to you and to me,
And to like him we all muſt for ever agree.
While he invites,
And pleaſure delights,
Who'll be ſo happy, ſo happy as we?

lg.head: III.
lg.l: 'T was CHARLEY that won the firſt prize of good boys,
The cockade and medal he wears and enjoys,
On his birth-day we all then, ſure, preſent muſt be,
And the tea, cakes and fruit are got ready you ſee.
While they invite,
And paſtimes delight,
There will none be ſo happy, ſo happy as we.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: WHEN BILLY was a little boy,
He then liv'd all alone;
Abroad his father had employ,
And mother he had none.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: So BILLY was unhappy quite,
But ſtill his book he read;
And learning ſtill was his delight,
Which to promotion led.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: The parſon was a man full kind,
The child when he obſerv'd;
As BILLY firſt had took his mind,
His love he ſtill preſerv'd.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: He taught him all good boys ſhould know,
BILLY each leſſon took;
While ſtudy is his full employ,
He profits by his book.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: Belov'd by all;—A merchant brave,
Took BILLY for his clerk;
Where he had all that boy could have,
And minded well his work.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: The maſter died—he had the trade,
And only daughter too;
And buſineſs all his ſtudy made,
Induſtrious did purſue.

lg.head: VII.
lg.l: His father now, return'd again,
His voyage being done;
With gold and jewels at command,
And Would aſſiſt his ſon.

lg.head: VIII.
lg.l: But BILLY wanted none of theſe;
With riches of his own,
He liv'd in grandeur and in eaſe,
And not (as once) alone.

lg.head: IX.
lg.l: For he had friends, and ſoon was made
An Alderman we find;
And, as his talents he diſplay'd
The city prov'd moſt kind.

lg.head: X.
lg.l: Lord Mayor of London, he at laſt,
In the gilt coach does ride,
See how he thro' the ſtreets doth paſs,
His lady by his ſide.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: WHAT a pretty kitten's here,
See how playful 'tis my dear;
Well does ſhe the time beguile,
Tho' you're ill, ſhe'd make you ſmile.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: But behold in all her pride,
Sitting by the fire ſide:
As if full of thoughts of weight,
Grave old Puſs is plac'd in ſtate.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Ev'ry thing the kitten views,
Sportive, happy, ſhe purſues;
Mouſe or paper cork and firing,
All alike can pleaſure brag.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Once her mother, full of game,
Play'd and friſk'd, and did the ſame;
To a mouſe ev'n now inclin'd,
Still "The cat is after kind."

lg.head: V.
lg.l: Time has all the diff'rence made,
The pow'r of Time's in all diſplay'd;
You, tho' full of merry play,
Will be grave another day.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: Youth's the time for joy and mirth,
Youth will give all pleaſures birth;
None your pleaſures will deſpiſe,
Be but MERRY, child, and WISE.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: YE children whom whimſies and follies prplex,
Whom paſſions miſguide, and impatience vez,
Who never with pleaſure your parents obey,
But are ſtill diſcontented, at reading or play.

l.hi: Attend to our counſel and we will declare,
How you may avoid all your follies and care.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Conſider of whom you were born, and how bed,
Conſider who gives you your board and your bed;
Remember by whom 'twas you firſt ſaw the light,
Remember who guards you by day and by night.

l.hi: Attend toour counſel, and hear us declare,
How you may avoid all your trouble and care.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Be always compliant and do what you're bid,
For that is the way you'll never be chid!
If your parents ſhould frown, by your ſmiles you may charm,
For the ſmiles of ſweet innoccence anger diſarm.

l.hi: Then attend to our counſel, and hear us declare,
How a child may avoid ev'ry trouble and care.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: To all your acquaintance be gentle and kind,
The advice of your elders be ſure that you mind;
Whatever they ſay, you will find for your good,
So let their inſtructions be always purſu'd

l.hi: Attend to our counſel for they will declare,
How a child may avoid ev'ry trouble and care.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: With your play-fellows never be wrangling nor croſs,
For they that are wranglers are ſure to have loſs;
But win by good humour the praiſes of thoſe,
Who may ſerve you as friends, or may hurt you as foes.

l.hi: Then attend to our counſels, and hear us declare,
How you may live happy, and avoid of all care.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: Do to all, as yourſelf you'd wiſh to be done by,
And ſcorn to tell tales, to ſpeak evil, or lie;
Fear God, love your parents, and honour the King,
And happineſs ſtill from your actions ſhall ſpring.

l.hi: Then attend to our counſels, and while thus we declare,
How you may live happy, and void of all care.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: OF ev'ry day that's in the week,
Good children ſhould love one day;
And plainly, my dear boy, to ſpeak,
The day I mean is Sunday.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: To church all decent folks then go,
There Charley, Billy, Harry,
And many others that we know,
Their little pray'r-books carry.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: And after Church abroad they walk,
Dreſt neatly as you find too;
Of good and ſerious things they talk,
And all are free and kind too.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Thro' fertile fields of verdant hue,
In ſummer as they rove;
God's goodneſs they with wonder view,
In valley, mead, and grove.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: In winter round the cheerful hearth,
They talk of ſports for Monday;
And full of ſweet and harmleſs mirth,
They paſs the hours of Sunday.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: Then of all days, tho' ſeven are ſeen,
Each week we'll pitch on one day;
And that's the day that comes between
The Saturday and Monday.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: COME my Charley, haſte away,
This is ſure a ſportful day;
See, Mamma has her deſign,
BETSEY is your VALENTINE.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Betſey whom Papa ſo lov'd,
Betſey by your friends approv'd;
See ſhe dreſt all gay and fine,
'Tis to be your VALENTINE.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: You have ſee a young Betſey's ways,
Well you know ſhe merits praiſe.
She's good-natur'd, lively, free,
Pattern fit for you and me.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: She at Eaſter cakes ſhail ſhare,
As ſhe did our Chriſtmas fare;
How could we make holiday,
If our Betſey was away.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: Then let's haſte with her to play,
On this fine and merry day;
Since it was Mamma's deſign,
Betſey ſhould be your VALENTINE.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: SEE the jolly train are reaping
Yellow ſheaves in order plac'd;
Harveſt home they'll ſoon be keeping,
And the beſt of cheer ſhall taſte.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Thoſe that labour to content ye,
Happily for you and me;
Well deſerve to feaſt in plenty,
As they do you'll plainly ſee.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Summer's bleſſings are delighting,
Then good children in the fields.
View the ſeaſon all delighting,
Taſte the cherries, plumbs, it yields.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Now the year is growing riper,
Peaches, apples, pears we find;
Merrily now plays the piper,
While the corn the reapers bind.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: Charley, Billy, Polly, Hetty,
View the ſeaſon with a ſmile;
Heav'n be ſure will never let ye
Want, while theſe for you ſhall toil.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: One reaps quick, the other binds it,
When well thraſh'd, on floors 'tis laid;
Then the jolly miller grinds it,
And it makes our daily bread.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: JACKEY was a pretty boy,
Jackey was his parent's joy;
But too often nurs'd and ſpoil'd,
Jackey grew a naughty child.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: On a ſultry ſummer's day,
Jackey would go out to play;
Left his ſchool and parents too,
Thinking pleaſure to purſue.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: There he ſaw the ſtreams all run,
Brightly glitt'ring in the ſun;
Naughty boys would ſwimming go,
Jackey likewiſe would do ſo.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: So he did;—but ſoon the tide,
Carried him far off and wide;
And his play mates quickly found
Jackey likely to be drown'd.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: One at length jump'd in to ſave,
Jackey from the dreadful wave;
See he wet and ſad does look,
Better he had learn'd his book.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: Home the naughty boy is brought,
And ſeverely told his fault;
See! he ſtays at home to-day,
While his ſchool-mates are at play.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: PRETTY little chidren come,
Tho' we have no ſports of May,
You may hear our Billy's drum,
And our Sammy's fiddle play.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: They have been abroad to buy,
Toys their parents to them gave;
See their little flags on high,
Full of pleaſure, how they wave!

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Firſt of all the throng is Charley,
On his flag is writ in gold;
How his parents love him dearly,
Few ſo good, though twice as old.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Next comes Harry, known to all,
None like him at cricket play;
Little as he is, the ball
He can ſtrike a wond'rous way.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: But theſe ſports are over now,
To the winter we muſt yield;
Winter calls the ſheep and cow,
Cold and ſhiv'ring from the field.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: Yet ſtill o'er the blazing fire,
Charley with our Kitty ſtands;
We can ſport to our deſire,
Play at queſtions and commands.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: IN infancy what joys appear,
To children only known;
For ſtill with each ſucceeding year,
Freſh pleaſures are their own.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Papa, Mamma, all joyful view,
Thoſe pleaſures ſtill improve;
And all your friends ſhall give you too
Some token of their love.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Alas, that roſes ſuch as theſe,
Should ever fade away;
But infancy which thus can pleaſe,
My dear muſt ſoon decay.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: The little lambs that friſking ſo,
All playful you behold;
Ere long, if they're alive, muſt go
All gravely to the fold.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: They muſt grow old, if life is ſpar'd,
So too muſt you and I;
The preſent moment then regard,
Nor for the future ſigh.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: In infancy may you my dear,
Your pleaſures ever find;
Pleaſures, that void of harm or fear,
Can leave no care behind.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: THIS, London is a fine place,
A great and gallant city;
And tho' not all are bleſt with grace,
The boys and girls are pretty.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: There is the wax-work to be ſhown,
And lions in the Tower;
And as full well to all is kuown,
New proſpects ev'ry hour.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: But Pretty they who pretty da,
Your parents often tell you;
And if you keep their lives in view,
You'll find they told full well too.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Tho' London is a place ſo fine,
And various beauties ſtrike you;
Yet at thoſe beauties you'll repine,
Unleſs the folks ſhould like you.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: Where'er you go, learn to be good,
And you will be rewarded;
And where (tho' little) you are view'd,
You ſtill will be rewarded.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: And when from London you are come,
That great and gallant city,
Be you but good and kind at home,
Still all things will be pretty.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: 'TIS the ſeaſon of mirth, boys, the people around,
All flock from their houſes while muſick does ſound;
'Tis the ſeaſon of mirth, boys, of frolick and play,
With the ſeaſon returning, returns Lord-May'rs Day.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: See the companies daily advance in their pride,
Along the ſmooth Thames ſee the barges ſwift glide;
What noſes! what ſhouting! the windows are lin'd,
With men, women, and children of ev'ry kind.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: See the Man all in armour rides on a fine horſe,
And all through the city he takes his full courſe;
If the fogs don't prevent you, his armour ſo bright,
Will pleaſe you at once, and will dazzle your ſight.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Laſt comes the Lord Mayor, his coach cover'd with gold
And the ſheriffs, a ſight that's quite fine to behold;
When the ſhow is all over, to feaſts they away,
And ſuch are the pleaſures of a Lord-May'rs Day,

lg.head: I.
lg.l: COME ſleep, my ſweet baby, the winds they will rock,
Yet nothing ſhall fright you, and nothing ſhall ſhock;
Sweet innocence guards you, on that ſtill depend,
For that will make ev'ry one Charley's dear friend.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: But the naughty boy, when the wind whiſtles, ſhall fear,
if the trees do but nod, he thinks danger is near;
So he's always in trouble, deſervdly ſo,
For the wicked and obſtinate never want woe.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: But you will ſleep ſoundly, your dreams will be ſweet,
And when you awake all your joys be complete;
For ſleeping or waking all pleaſures we find,
Depend on the charms of an innocent mind.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Then ſleep on my baby, the winds as they blow,
Shall on you ſtill ſlumbers and ſafety beſtow
Smile, ſmile, my dear Charley, for you may depend,
That Heav'n ſhall your innocence ever befriend.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: PEACEFUL do the waters flow,
Gentle winds as peaceful blow,
Thus, my child, from fretting ceaſe,
Huſh, your paſſions into peace.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: When the bluſt'ring ſtorms ariſe,
See how frightful look the ſkies;
But when calm, the proſpect bright,
Glads you with the beauteous light.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Calm the proſpect of the mind,
When your temper's mild you'll find,
Then are you like ſmiling May,
When the flow'ry Spring is gay.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: But when crying, you deform
That pretty face, and fret and ſtorm;
Like November's dreary day,
Then you fright your friends away.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: Then as waters gently flow,
When the breezes ſoftly blow;
Do you be peaceable and mild,
Fret no more my pretty child.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: A SPIDER once his web had ſpun,
And thought he dwelt ſecurely
In a ſnug corner it was run,
And as he thought full ſurely.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Many a thoughtleſs fly he caught,
And ſoon his fate decided;
Grown proud at laſt, he vainly tho't
All foes to have derided.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: So high his cobweb ſeat he built,
So well he had deſign'd it,
That while he gloried in his guilt,
Not Molly's broom could find it.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: At length, one Summer's morn, a Bee
Came humming round the ceiling.
And ſoon, like many others, ſhe Entangled without feeling.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: The Spider from his ſecret cell,
Came out with thoughts moſt pleaſing;
And with a leap he practis'd well,
At once his prey was ſeizing.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: But the ſtrong Bee his web deſtroy'd
And the ſly felon wounded;
Thus ere his conqueſt he enjoy'd,
His ſchemes were all confounded.

lg.head: VII.
lg.l: Stung to the quick, he now withdrew,
And made a diſmal moan;
The Bee with honey loaded flew,
The Spider died alone.

lg.head: VIII.
lg.l: Thus wretches who work other's woe,
A while with joy relate;
When unexpected ills they know,
Unpity'd meet their fate.

div.head: DIRECTIONS FOR ALL GOOD BOYS AND GIRLS TO FOLLOW.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: WHEN early in the morn you riſe,
And ſhake off ſlumber from your eyes,
Fail not to pray to God on high,
To ſhow'r his bleſſings from the ſky

lg.head: II.
lg.l: And when you've ſaid your morning pray'r,
Let cleanlineſs be next your care,
Your hair be comb'd, your face and hands
Be waſh'd, as decency commands.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Next mind in time vou get to ſchool,
And there obſerve each proper rule;
Sit ſtill and ſteady; on your book,
But not on other matters, look.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: To learning if you will attend,
Learning will prove your greateſt friend
Dunces for ever meet with ſhame,
And never riſe to worth or fame.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: But thoſe who to their book attend,
Shall always meet thro' life a friend;
And, howſoe'er their lot is caſt,
If wiſe, will come to good at laſt.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: Before your meals repeat your grace,
Then ſit contented in your place;
Nor aſk for any thing, but wait
Till meat be put upon your plate.

lg.head: VII.
lg.l: Sit upright, never forward lean,
From greaſe be ſure that you keep clean;
Nor look around with greedy eye,
Nor eat too much of fav'rite pye.

lg.head: VIII.
lg.l: Sit ſti1l 'till you are bid retire,
Nor croud too cloſe o'er winter fire;
Obſerve what all good children do,
And keep their pattern ſtill in view.

lg.head: IX.
lg.l: Never be heard too loud to ſpeak,
Only when aſk'd your ſilence break;
Be ſure your elders to obey,
Nor e'er be quarrelſome at play.

lg.head: X.
lg.l: Never bear tales, or you will be
Hated by all you hear and ſee;
Mind but yourſelf—let others do
Juſt as they pleaſe;—'tis nought to you.

lg.head: XI.
lg.l: Be of a temper kind and mild,
For that will beſt become a child;
A wrangler none can e'er approve,
But gentleneſs ſecures you love.

lg.head: XII.
lg.l: If ever you ſhould chance to meet
A common beggar in the ſtreet,
Do not with ſcorn that beggar view,
The God that made him, did make you.

lg.head: XIII.
lg.l: On ſchool-mates never lay the fault,
If you have done what you ought not,
Believe me, child, howe'er you cry.
'Tis always beſt to ſcorn a lie.

lg.head: XIV.
lg.l: To ev'ry one give honour due,
And they'll return their love to you;
There's none ſo high, there's none ſo low,
But yet may prove a friend or foe.

lg.head: XV.
lg.l: But chief of all your parents prize,
it you'd be bleſs'd, if you'd be wiſe,
Tho' now perhaps not underſtood,
All that they ſay is for your good.

lg.head: XVI.
lg.l: DO you a juſt example take,
I'll ways in proper time forſake,
Your ſafety ne'er can be enſur'd,
But by your parent's care ſecur'd.

lg.head: XVII.
lg.l: In all your thoughts, at work or play,
Your teachers ſtil1 ſhould bear the ſway;
Nor e'er keep company with thoſe,
Who other thoughts or words diſcloſe.

lg.head: XVIII.
lg.l: When tir'd at night to bed you go,
Sleep quiet, as no cares you know,
Again your pray'rs to heav'n addreſt,
No doubt an infant ſhall be bleſt.

lg.head: XIX.
lg.l: In ev'ry caſe let children own
They have no will that is their own;
And, tho' above their years, their wit,
Still to ſuperiours mild ſubmit.

lg.head: XX.
lg.l: Sweetneſs and goodneſs be their praiſe,
For theſe will laſt to other days;
The time will come when they ſhall prove,
That children's goodneſs gains Heav'n's love.
READ o'er theſe pleaſing lines with care, my dear,
For you alone are they inſerted here;
Songs wrote to pleaſe you, tales for you deſign'd,
Both to divert you, and improve your mind.
Whatever you in earlieſt days are taught,
Is thus, by care, to juſt perfection brought;
Yet ſtill amuſement we ſhall here beſtow,
For with amuſement ſhould inſtruction go.
Our verſes are contriv'd for ev'ry ear,
And you muſt underſtand them when you hear:
Then to our rhymes a pleas'd attention give,
And you will taſte their profits while you live.
To little ones our rhymes are now addreſs'd,
Great ones may profit by the truths expreſs'd.
Then let not any thing prevent your claim,
To take what leads you ſtill to worth and fame.
In every line a moral fair is ſhewn,
Children may make that moral ſtill their own;
And, if they take it, ſhall in future days,
Succeed to wealth, to happineſs, and praiſe.
